content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												FTL:Faster Than Light is rouge like space-simulator made by indie developer Subset Games where you play a Federation Fleet Commander of a small courier ship holding vital information on the Rebellions new ship that could face destroy the Federation grip on the galaxy.  Along the way, you will make friends and unite together to stop the rebels. Or more accurately you will bumble through several sectors with half the crew you started out with, absolutely zero scrap and a ship held together with the chewed up bubblegum, spit and the sheer willpower of fi-And you're space debris.Lovely.FTL as the introduction suggests, has you exploring various randomly generated sectors where you gather scrap, unlock new and better ships with benefits (and minuses of course) till you reach the final boss fight. Which you won't. Unless you are extremely lucky and even then. You may as well pat yourself on the back for making it that far. Because the rebel flagship will send you straight to the start faster than two shakes of a lamb's tail. You may think I'm complaining. But believe me, that is exactly what I love about FTL. It's hard. Therefore you must think of a plan and organise your crew. Who you will grow affectionate towards until you have to send one of them into the fire of oxygenator  to repair it while you and your surviving crew members cower in the med-bay. The game will keep you going for hours and hours, dying and replaying, dying and replaying and then dying some more. You can unlock various ships by completing a series of complex quests that you will /never/ find out how to complete without looking up a guide how to do it or at least  what I had to do. The random encounters are a nice touch but I found myself getting the same ones over and over again. With the odd variation. For example, I will pick up a Mantis crewman stranded on a planet and he will join my crew on one run. But on the next, he will stab my shield operator in the gullet and teleport onto a level three shielded ship. The randomness is both a thing I love and hate in equal measure and while I like the unforgivingness of this game many others will not. But you came to read my opinion, not others.Right now FTL is on sale at £2.09, which is an absolute steal and may as well be throwing it on mass through people's windows. I recommend getting it and while you're at it. Nominate it for an award. God knows it deserves it.It might make you racist against Mantis, though.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												A very good strategy game that runner-up for numerous strategy game of the year awards, second only to X-COM.You manage a ship containing crew members and try to survive till the last sector. There is a huge variety of alien race available as crew members with their strengths and weaknesses.Your ship can also have a variety of weapons like beams, missiles, drones, even a teleporter that allows you to beam your crew members to the enemy ship to try and take it by brute force.You also have to balance your ship's power to support various rooms like oxygen, shields, weapons, and cloaking. This also means there are many ways to defeat your enemies other than destroying it, such as burning them out with fire, and depriving them of oxygen.The only con is that this game is random, and what weapons or crew members you can get depends on luck. Most of the time you cannot get your ideal setup. But the game allows unlockable ships which start out in a certain way. So that alleviates the randomness a bit.A must-buy for strategy game fans.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												An addictive fun game.Faster than light (FTL) is a very addictive and fun game set in the "Space simulation" genre.Don't let the graphics deter you from buying the game, graphics doesn't equal to fun.The game has great replayability as nothing is the same on your next playthrough, every new playthrough is totally random and can either let you go on free of harm or totally mess you up.in FTL you control a ship, which is called "The Kestrel" by default, but you can rename it. with this ship you also control your crew, power, upgrades and your choices you make when prompted.   When starting the first playthrough you will be greeted with the selection screen and your 3 crew mates, as you go on through the game you unlock new ships and upgrades to play with on your next playthrough...that is of course if you can get through the sectors easily and not be deemed "Unfit" by the RNG lords....The RNG used in this game is fantastic, at times you will get frustrated with it and at other times you will be thankful for it.I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a game with great replay value!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												FTL:Faster Than Light is rouge like space-simulator made by indie developer Subset Games where you play a Federation Fleet Commander of a small courier ship holding vital information on the Rebellions new ship that could face destroy the Federation grip on the galaxy.  Along the way, you will make friends and unite together to stop the rebels. Or more accurately you will bumble through several sectors with half the crew you started out with, absolutely zero scrap and a ship held together with the chewed up bubblegum, spit and the sheer willpower of fi-And you're space debris.Lovely.FTL as the introduction suggests, has you exploring various randomly generated sectors where you gather scrap, unlock new and better ships with benefits (and minuses of course) till you reach the final boss fight. Which you won't. Unless you are extremely lucky and even then. You may as well pat yourself on the back for making it that far. Because the rebel flagship will send you straight to the start faster than two shakes of a lamb's tail. You may think I'm complaining. But believe me, that is exactly what I love about FTL. It's hard. Therefore you must think of a plan and organise your crew. Who you will grow affectionate towards until you have to send one of them into the fire of oxygenator  to repair it while you and your surviving crew members cower in the med-bay. The game will keep you going for hours and hours, dying and replaying, dying and replaying and then dying some more. You can unlock various ships by completing a series of complex quests that you will /never/ find out how to complete without looking up a guide how to do it or at least  what I had to do. The random encounters are a nice touch but I found myself getting the same ones over and over again. With the odd variation. For example, I will pick up a Mantis crewman stranded on a planet and he will join my crew on one run. But on the next, he will stab my shield operator in the gullet and teleport onto a level three shielded ship. The randomness is both a thing I love and hate in equal measure and while I like the unforgivingness of this game many others will not. But you came to read my opinion, not others.Right now FTL is on sale at £2.09, which is an absolute steal and may as well be throwing it on mass through people's windows. I recommend getting it and while you're at it. Nominate it for an award. God knows it deserves it.It might make you racist against Mantis, though.

content:
Posted: February 18
												A lone federation ship must pass through a gauntlet of hostile alien space systems in the brutally difficult roguelike sci-fi adventure FTL. Just like its namesake, you must navigate each system by making faster-than-light jumps between locations and discovering new worlds and challenges all while fleeing a rapidly advancing rebel fleet while carrying the secret of how to defeat its most fearsome weapon: the rebel flagship.Gameplay in FTL is simple and straightforward. You can move crew from room to room in your ship, leaving them at stations like pilot, engine, and shields to boost the efficiency of those systems. Attacks are all performed by clicking weapons and then clicking on the enemy ship on the right side of the screen. Power management is also a big part of the game with reactor energy being scarce at times and requiring you to juggle allocation to specific systems when needed. Occasionally enemies will also teleport into your ship (something you can also do) and you will have to move crew around to fight or flee.This game is both really forgiving and also really unforgiving as far as roguelikes go. For example, if the rebel fleet does actually catch up to you, you have a chance to escape and it’s not an immediate game over. Having specific species of crew or ship systems will often give you blue dialogue options which are guaranteed to be successful. On the other hand, the RNG can be downright brutal and some runs will be doomed to failure if you cannot accrue the necessary weapons and systems to face the final boss. Certain ship configurations, such as the stealth ship, are especially vulnerable to bad RNG and will require many a restart before you finally get the right mix.Despite its crazy high difficulty, FTL is really fun and you’ll likely find yourself spending hours and hours trying to win without even realizing it until you check your clock and notice you’ve spent half a day flying around in space.

												This game is wonderful - 10/10Graphics - 9/10 The art style is made up of wonderfully nostalgic 2D images, with a typical over head view of the action the players point of view has been tested through time in the RTS genre and cannot be faulted. My only bug bear is I'd like a little more customisation for my ships/crew colours etc.Sound - 10/10 The sound is also pretty nostalgic for anyone who played games before the mid 90s, the melodic theme is catchy and non-invasive while the sound effects are exactly what you'd expect, the lazers. bombs and shields all sound perfect.Gameplay - 10/10 The quick paced gameplay is exhilerating, managing your crew is vital and tense strategic decisions arise regularly in combat on each playthrough. The inclusion of a pause function is vital to your survival as when the more intense battles take place every second is vital! The very inclusion of a pause function makes the game much more accessible to newcomers of strategy. A save upon exit function (no going back to your save if you die) reflects the games Rogue-Like roots. Overall - 10/10 This is one of my favourite games, it's hard there is no sugar coating it, but oh so addictive!A must buy title in my eyes!

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												In space, no one will hear your ship's hull being disintegrated... multiple times.FTL is a space-themed rouge-lite that succeeds on two levels. One, the writing, world, events and story are surprising catalyst, that gives you that long waited feel of being a captain on the space-worthy craft. Mechanics of managing the ship are simple, yet really complex and game likes to throw you into plethora of different problems to solve while running away from the rebels. Building your crew, repairing and upgrading ship, encountering aliens, both friendly and not, space combat... it really brings the fantasy to life even with the minimalistic presentation. You will certainly enjoy the moment to moment, self-story building, least before the moment when game runs out of unique random encounters.Then, the second main positive comes it. Variety of game options, mechanics, different ships or playstyles you can incorporate. During your journey you will unlock many different ships that operate on drastically different premises, that make multiple playthoughs an enjoyable experience, despite you knowing the exact odds of Giant Space Spiders eating your crew. FTL stops being narrative-oriented here and becomes hardcore game of judging risk and different choices. It's unbelievable how addicting this is and many meaningful strategic decisions you can make. Playtime doesn't lie, replayability is right here.I extremely enjoyed time spent on this title. While beating the game was certainly hard, the satisfaction of doing so gives just enough kick to you for the next space voyage. Highly recommended!

												This game is wonderful - 10/10Graphics - 9/10 The art style is made up of wonderfully nostalgic 2D images, with a typical over head view of the action the players point of view has been tested through time in the RTS genre and cannot be faulted. My only bug bear is I'd like a little more customisation for my ships/crew colours etc.Sound - 10/10 The sound is also pretty nostalgic for anyone who played games before the mid 90s, the melodic theme is catchy and non-invasive while the sound effects are exactly what you'd expect, the lazers. bombs and shields all sound perfect.Gameplay - 10/10 The quick paced gameplay is exhilerating, managing your crew is vital and tense strategic decisions arise regularly in combat on each playthrough. The inclusion of a pause function is vital to your survival as when the more intense battles take place every second is vital! The very inclusion of a pause function makes the game much more accessible to newcomers of strategy. A save upon exit function (no going back to your save if you die) reflects the games Rogue-Like roots. Overall - 10/10 This is one of my favourite games, it's hard there is no sugar coating it, but oh so addictive!A must buy title in my eyes!

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												FTL: Faster Than Light is a roguelike or rather rogue-lite title that has characteristics of strategy and simulation games. The player is in control of a starship that is fleeing from the powerful rebel forces. The ship needs to get to the fleet command and warn them before it is too late. On your way you come through various randomly generated sectors. You cannot stay in one sector for too long as the rebel forces are closing in on you and take over more of the map every turn.When I first saw footage of the game I was mildly confused. Was that one screen really all you see during the game? Yes, it actually is. That's not a bad thing, though. In the main part of the screen you always see your ship from above. If there is an enemy ship it will be displayed on the right. While fights are played in real-time the map screen is turn based. On the sector map you can perform one FTL jump per turn to get to a beacon. Most beacons have a random event when you first jump there. That event can be something that just happens, like a sudden fight or something that you find. In most cases however a window pops up and you can choose from several options. Depending on your ships systems, subsystems and crew more options become available. Your ship is equipped with various systems and subsystems. All of those, as well as the ship's raw "attributes" can be upgraded with scrap. You can also use scrap to buy additional systems and subsystems as well as weapons or crew members or just have your ship repaired.Fights are played in real-time. Luckily you can pause and give orders whenever you want. Every weapon has a certain preparation time before it can shoot and can be aimed at any of the enemy ship's rooms. If a room with a system receives a direct hit that system is damaged and has to be repaired. There is, depending on the weapon, also a possibility for a fire or a hull breach. During a fight you have to micromanage your crew to keep the ship functional. If there is system damage the crew can fix it. They can also repair hull breaches and put out fires. It is however also beneficial to have your crew man certain systems since it raises the particular system's effectivity and the piloting system does not even work properly without a crew member to man it. It is also possible to open and close doors given the door system is working. Opening doors to space can be very beneficial to put out fires or suffocate boarders.There is a number of races that can all join your crew. Every race has unique characteristics and some of them give you special options in random events. There are various unlockable ship types and layouts for each type. Those don't simply change the room layout but also the starting systems and crew. So your playstyle will not only vary per ship but also per layout.On the one hand  FTL: Faster Than Light is due to its random generation to a certain extent luck based. On the other hand however there is much room for creativity and strategy. There is a multitude of ship systems and weapons to choose from. Every race has its advantages (and some of them have disadvantages too). There are many meaningful choices to make and if you play for a while you can see yourself getting better every time.I can definitely recommend this to anybody who likes rogue-lites, strategy or simulation games.More reviews here

												I almost expect my breath to frost the glass of the view screen before me.  Space is cold, after all.I shake off my uneasiness as the docking clamps are disengaged.  The FTL Drive that delivered us to this point powers down, light thrusters coming online to keep it from drifting from its beacon.I push power to the engines, jumping the ship to a nearby beacon.As soon as we arrive, we are fired upon by a Rebel ship.  A missile hits our shield generator, allowing a concentrated beam to slice through our oxygen production generator, and our engines in one clean cut.  I order our oxygen brought back online; we're sitting ducks without our engine, but we'll die without oxygen even if we survive this encounter.Rapid blaster fire pelts our hull, damaging our weapons systems enough to take our main weapon offline.I fire our last missile in a last ditch attempt to shake them off of us, only to watch in despair as they cloak, the missile passing them entirely.As fire engulfs our systems and our oxygen levels drop below even the danger zone, my only solace is in knowing that the cloning facility will soon come online, and I'll have another go.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												FTL is one of those games that became popular due to internet celebrities streaming it, not because it's outstanding. Dying on turn one is no fun in any game.This is one of those games that is better to watch someone else play than to play yourself, go watch it on twitch or youtube, you'll get a better experience.I'm not saying the game is bad but I personally just can't get into it. The game is played by you making jumps from one system/planet to another while the rebel fleet chase you down, which is fine but each jump can literally be game over and so its a glorified mine sweeper.Its a game someone can watch you play and it will seem exciting but the reality is that the base concept of the game is dull and the metagame of maximizing scrap so you can run the typical build order also dull for example; No matter what, if you are in sector 1, then get 2 shields.Sitting still against an enemy that has no hopes of getting through your shields, is a good idea for skill level ups.Kill everyone and everything because then you get more scrap. So on and so forth.I don't feel like I need to adapt to whats going on, just that I am going through the motions again and again. Every single time I deviated from the 'plan' such as trying a new weapon or going for a different build order, I get killed. As long as I do the same thing over and over during the early turns, I will be fine. You don't even need to take my word for it as if you are reading this on steam then you can just go to the guides section and they will explain exactly the same thing. It is the illusion of choice because there is only 1 way to build your ship in the early game if you want to survive the late game.The games music drones on comepletely ignoring current events and is otherwise unremarkable. I don't feel like the USS enterprise or other space fantasy captains, the music sounds disjointed from the game and just sounds generic. Normally I wouldn't point this out except for the fact the soundtrack is sold seperately, save your money.You need to get scrap in order to do aything such as upgrade your ship or buy shop parts, but those are random so you can only buy what you are lucky enough to get, just like a deck building card game. I don't really mind because that is also the nature of rogue-likes but what I do mind is that you can die very quickly in sector 1 because your first jump is a rebel ship that just happens to counter your ship perfectly. Its rare but it does happen. Later on after sector 1, enemy ships seem to just "randomly" have subsystems that perfectly counter your build which also leads to the wonderful metagame of gaming the game and that seems to be all the guides and all the videos I watched about this game. If you want to deviate from the cookie cutter build then you just have to 'trick' the game and that gets really boring.The last boss is the perfect example of 'gaming the game'. If you kill the crew in regular fights then you win. Against the last boss this isn't the case, instead the last boss gets harder! So instead you kill everyone except the one person who mans the lasers because lasers can't hurt you if you have your shields up meaning you can kill that form of the last boss at your leisure. Last boss has 3 forms by the way, because why wouldn't it. No you don't heal in between rounds, its a 'rogue-like' so its supposed to be "hard". The game has potential and free DLC was also made for the game which is always great. Overall I recommend this game simply because if you don't like the game, you will very easily find out very, very quickly in time to get a refund and if you do like the game then you don't really care what I, or anyone else says. For me personally I would like it if the game encouraged experimentation. So many builds or weapon combos are just going to get you killed and its infuriating that such suicidal options are even incuded.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

Posted: February 21, 2014
												Sigh...I...cannot in good faith recommend this game.  Not to everyone.  Is it bad?  Hell no.  This game is remarkably polished in a number of aspects.  The problem is, the game isn't very fun.  At least not in the long run.  When you start off, you will be full of wonder, piloting your starship into unknown realms, trying to save the your allies from the rebels!  Then you'll die, lose everything and have to start over again.  This pattern will repeat for about 20 times before you become super frustrated and give up on the game.Let me reiterate...FTL is not a bad game.  It is damn good.  However, it fails in one crucial way.  It does not give you a feeling of incremental progress.  Some may like the challenge that that brings, but for a rogue-like to be worth your time these days, with so many other rogue-likes out there, it needs to make your time meaningful.  FTL is a time waster...it will kill you over and over again and it will be due to randomness, not to any fault of your own.  And seldom ever will the game change or improve.  Of the over 10 ships to unlock, I got...four.  After many failed attempts.  By accident.  Each death was just as frustratingly stupid and unavoidable as the last.If you like that, fine, have at it, the game's mechanics are solid, but...FTL just wastes my time.  And I cannot recommend it on those merits alone.

Posted: June 25, 2016
												This game is really fun and challenging when you start playing it becuase you can feel that the game mechanics give it a lot of depth and you wan't wait to learn how the game works so you can figure out how to win and develop strategies. But as you keep playing it, you slowly begin to realize how wrong you were, and that the reality is there is no depth to the game because everything that happens depends almost entirely on luck and how little anything you actually do matters.You can play flawlessly, making all the right decisions, buying all the right upgrades to turn your ship into the perfect combat vessel that can dodge most shots, has the shields to absorb whatever manages to get through and still has a powerful enough armament to destroy anything you come across, but it won't matter because in the next battle suddenly you will be forced into a situation that is literally impossible to survive. This isn't fun, this isn't good gameplay, it's just terrible game design (or lack thereof) and I really wish people would stop making excuses for games whose developers bought into the fallacy that "everything determined by RNG = hard = good game" because it never works.And the most frustrating thing is that this is by no means a bad game. It is otherwise very well designed and is actually really fun as long as the RNG isn't arbitrarily killing you off. The only thing the game has to do to improve is to reduce the supremacy of the RNG in determining everything that happens and to let the player's actions have more influence. I don't care if they leave in a "hardcore mode" or call less random mode "baby difficulty" or whatever, I just want to enjoy playing a game.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I was unfamiliar with the "roguelike"-genre when I first played FTL and I fell in love at once. Both with the genre and the game itself.The combat is rewarding and surprisingly deep. You, as a player, have a lot of agency when choosing what to build and how to engage enemies.There are, also, some random events when you're asked to make moral decitions. These don't inpact the game in any grand way; there are no "good vs evil"-morality bars that you fill up. They only leave you with less money and a sense that you did a good thing (if that's what you're into).The gameplay is, like I described, very good but the real strength of the game is the world and atmosphere. The alien races are well defined, the random encounters are well written and the music is fantastic.I cannot recommed this game enough.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Faster Than Light is one of the most entertaining games I have ever played, and certainly one of the more challenging games around. This game will make you think hard, play hard and lose hard.The atmosphere of the game is compelling. The music that accompanies you through your journeys is enjoyable, and the sense of eternal doom and damnation is always upon you.There are a fair number of ships, which all have different emphasis on certain tactics. Therefore, there is always one that appeals to your style of playing. The environment is ever-changing; not two games are alike, thus the game always has new surprises in store for you. With the new Advanced Edition, there is even additional content for free!However, the game can be exceptionally difficult, even on the easiest difficulty. This might discourage many players from playing or even finishing the game. Do not get discouraged, though, as you eventually will find a way to defeat the last boss, and when you do, a glorious sensation of victory awaits.With that said, FTL is a great game that offers many hours of quality play time. Each new game will pose new challenges that can be solved in different ways. However, you are bound to fail most of the time, so, arm yourself with patience, and good luck.This indie game deserves a total of 10/10, worth every penny

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Honestly, if you've not heard of FTL, then stop reading this post, go to the store page, and click on the 'Buy' button right now. It's an utterly fantastic masterpeice of a RTS in space. So, now that I have that out of the way, what is FTL? What makes is deserve the title of an, 'utterly fantasitc masterpiece? To start off, FTL is a Real Time Strategy where you captain a crew of subordinate sprites with the sole duty of keeping them alive as you meander your way through the galaxy. If you've ever wanted to be the captain of a ship like the Enterprise, than this is the game for you. Divert energy from weapon systems and pump them to shields. Command your crew to extinguish a fire in the Med Bay. Make the command decision to place your trust a sketchy alien species.Survive the fight against a ship 2X larger than you against all odds.  Oh, by the way, did I mention that it's a rougelike? No? Than, It's a rougelike. You're expected to die on almost every playthrough, even on easy. However, because of this system, the unlock structure is bloody difficult. Most ships you unlock by beating the game. So with every endgame win, you unlock a new, beefier and/or shinier vessel. This game is not without flaws, however I definitly reccomend this game 100% to anyone interested in a new Strategy-Rougelike expirence. 9/10-Mattorious

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Have you ever spent months cultivating a rare plant only for it to spontanously combust into flames one evening while watering the little fella? Have you ever finally worked up the courage to ask that cutie you've been crushing on all year only to have a giant mantis rip off the lunch room ceiling and devour her head-first? Have you ever been to Flint, Michigan?If so then this is the game for you, where you watch as you fruitlessly surge ever onwards towards your goal, despite no matter how prepared you actually are. You will form bonds with your tiny pixelated crew members as you care for their well being and watch them risk life and limb to save their other comrades and the ship- all in a futile effort to prolong the inevitable. And it is only when your last remaining crew member dies, gasping for breath while trying to fix the O2 pump as missiles and gatling-laser fire spank across the ruined hull of your once beautiful ship will you realize that this game is a deceptively sinister mistress. Spiraling you ever onwards to a eventual loss and sense of remorse and guilt while you ponder off what went wrong with the image of your frozen crew members listing aimlessly through the void of space to give you solace. Also has an amazing soundtrack to listen to as you and everyone you have grown attatched to in the last 35 minutes dies a horrible death. 10/10

												If Mass Effect were turned into a 2D game, this would be a very good representation of the outcome.  While the story itself is simple, the game play mechanics are sound and complex.  How you build your ship, who you help, how you fight your battles, and what you choose to focus on have major impacts on the outcomes of your journeys.  I bought the game and got hooked into 4 hours of game play on the first night.  The developers put in some nice features that allow people who don't like real time strategy as much to play the game in near turn base with an easy to use autofire and pause any time mechanic.  I'm just scratching the surface and I'm already giving it all the thumbs.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is extremely fun and challenging.  Its a great game for 10 bucks and when it goes on sale it is an absolute steal.  Basically this game is Star Trek hardcore version.  Negotiating is not always an option and it can be difficult to know when to run and when to fight.  Its a rogue like exploration game with a great combat element to it.  You manage and upgrade your ship while trying to stay ahead of those dang rebels.  Its a game that is easy to learn the basics of, but very difficult to master.  I have beat it many times now, but it took me a very long time to understand how best to manage my resources and required a lot of fun experimenting in order to win (it also took many many hours to finally beat the game the first time).  I'm am still finding new ways to play this game and loving every minute of it.  I can't recommend this game enough.  And if anyone wants a funny and entertaining review of this game look  up pyrion flax FTL, and watch his guide to the game.  Yes this game is difficult and sometimes unforgiving, but it is so much fun to play.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												10/10An absolutely brilliant game that is a must-own for almost anyone, it’s endlessly replayable and presents a very distinct challenge. Its complexity doesn’t come from overwhelming the player – all the mistakes you make will be your own fault – it’s just brilliantly designed in that it requires instant critical thinking in battles and a thoughtful approach while traversing the galaxy and encountering unknown or enemy vessels. The perma-death element is what gives the game its replay value – a single session could last 15 minutes to two hours depending on your skill (and luck); dying in this game is really just a learning experience. The unlockables don’t necessarily make the game any easier and the only way you will advance further is by refining your approach. I find myself coming back to the game time and time again to see how far I can make it.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												This game is basically Firefly meets Oregon Trail.  It's not really about space combat, it's about crew management.  Combat is distilled down to two ships sitting there firing away at each other, with all actual "flight" abstracted away.  Instead, everything is a series of rolls under the hood, and you have to target enemy subsystems to weaken them in combat.  The core of the gameplay is trying to balance a million things going on at once.  Your lasers are ready to fire, but you want to wait until the shield-piercing missiles have recharged so you can disable the shield first.  There's also a fire in the engine room which is lowering your dodge chance, but you can't get someone there yet to put it out because boarders have started a fight in the gunnery room.  Meanwhile, you're taking fire from the enemy ship.  Luckily you can pause at any time to queue up orders and think out your plan.If that paragraph appeals to you, get it.  It's frantic gameplay with randomly generated events and drops that will make every playthrough different.  There's a ton of unique crewmember races, weapon types, ship types, and dynamic events.  They just added a free expansion pack which adds new mechanics and systems and events.  Absolutely amazing game.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												As of the time of writing, I've logged 36 hours playing FTL. It still doesn't feel like enough, and it probably never will, thanks to the exceptional variety and replayability of this particular indie gem.FTL is the answer to the fantasies of anyone who experienced Star Trek, Star Wars, Firefly, Babylon 5, Battlestar Galactica, Farscape, Futurama, or any of a million science-fiction programmes, novels and films, and thought 'I wish I could do that'. And it absolutely lives up to its potential. Beginning with a small ship and a handful of crew, the player must navigate a vast network of star systems, overcoming pirates, solar flares, asteroid fields, slave traders, and the constant pursuit of the Rebel fleet. Death stalks your crew at every turn, and your actions can mean the difference between a swift death in the vacuum and living to fight another day.The mechanics are uncomplicated and impressively well-designed. Ship's systems are powered up and down, crewmates man their stations, usually under heavy fire and whilst trying to affect vital repairs, while a fire rages through the ship and enemy boarders swarm the corridors. FTL is a roguelike game, so re-loading a saved game to try again from the same point isn't an option - if you're dead, you're dead, and you've got to start again from the hangar screen.This can be infuriating at first, but the challenge is well worth taking on. Under such trying conditions, reaching a new sector or beating a previous high-score become truly satisfying achievements. Not to mention the fleet of playable ships which can be gradually unlocked, adding some choice to the starting conditions.FTL provides - as the Vulcans say - (almost) infinite diversity in infinite combinations. Each playthrough is different, with a different crew and different choices, and even the most disastrous run can amount to more staisfaction than some games manage on their best day.If that isn't enough, the creators are planning the release of a new DLC - free of charge - some time in early 2014, featuring a new species, new ships, new weapons, and tweaks to gameplay that should streamline and improve the already impressive experience. FTL frequently features in Steam sales, but it's worth every penny of the full price, and I can only reccomend that you buy it and start playing as soon as possible.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												This game looked intricate at the beginning, and was deciptively so, but i quickly managed to pick up the user-interface and proceded to play through the first few sectors of the game.The real-time battles are fun, managing internal and external factors of your ship, attacking whilst keeping everything intact, it's rather challenging, especially in the later levels. That said though, this game has a moderate difficulty curve which, if approached badly, will guarantee failure in the long-term.The game utilises a single-run system, every time you die, you reset back to a base version of a ship. Now I dont mind this system too much, but when you progress fairly far into the game, and are suddenly attacked by a massively overpowered enemy which eventually kills you, it makes you want to go back to change things, but alas, all is lost upon death. And with the upgrading system implemented into the game, this becomes an irritating factor.Nontheless, this was a game that has been sitting in my steam library for quite some time now, neglected by my overwhelming masses of things i have yet to play (aka, the humble bundle effect), but I really enjoyed the few hours that i've spent on it so far, and I will definately advise other people to give this game a shot, fair warning to the difficulty though.

												the word rouge-like gets throw around a lot. It seems there is a bigger craze for "indie rouge-likes" now more than the DOOM clones of the 90s. Rouge Legacy, Legend of the Dungeon, Sword of the Stars, Dungeon of the Endless, Angband, tales of Majisomething, Spelunky, Paranautical Activity, seriously, like this stuff stacks up quick. Although FTL is one of these rouge-likes, it stands unique and apart from the others. FTL is a beautiful space exploration game with a very well done art style and good ship design. The randomized elements keep each play through fresh, which is good, because you will have several run throughs trying to beat this game. it took me 21 hours and 50 something tries to beat the game once on easy. While that sounds insanley difficult and frustrating, the shortness of each run through (the victory took 2 hours, while most runs were 30 minutes) stops most of the frustration. In fact, dying 30 minutes in gives a nice little taste of gaming. Busy? Hop into your starship and run a few sectors before being blasted apart by slavers. or borded by mantuis. or being cooked alive by a dying star. or being trapped behind enemy lines like the millenium falcon in the empire strikes back.A great game, great stories, good combat. not much more you can ask for.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Strangely addicting, FTL is a fun game that makes a lot out of a little.  The graphics are not fancy, but that quickly disappears when you really get into the game.  The premise is simple: get to the Federation with your secret data without being destroyed.  Death is permanent.  When you die (and you will, often) you don't go back to the last save.  You go all the way back to the beginning.  Space can be brutal.  However, play through again...and again.  While you had previously been ripped apart in level 2, you now get to level six every time.  You pick up crew and lose them.  You choose weapons as you come upon them and each battle has the opportunity to be your last.  For the price, it is certainly worth a buy.  I have found it oddly addicting and, of course, it plays on any old Mac or PC.  A solid recommendation to buy if you like the thinking man's space shooter.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												FTL: Faster Than Light is one of the best games I've played. Simple to pick up, but difficult to beat. As you play through you unlock new ships or layouts for ships you have already unlocked. There are 9 ships available, 8 of which need to be unlocked. Each ship has a type B layout, some off which make the game easier, others making the game more difficult.Along with everything mentioned above, there is mod support. Mods for the game range from Star trek ships to Infinite Space.The only problem I have with the game is one of the ships (The Crystal Ship) is too difficult to unlock. To unlock it, you need to get the damaged stasis pod, take it to an Engi or Zoltan sector then head to a Rock Homeworld, then survive through the crystal homeworlds sector to unlock the ship. Other than that, good game. Throw all your money at it.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2012
												I always liked the gameplay of roguelikes but was never really into the typical fantasy setting they were framed in. This, though, this is neat. A space roguelike. Over half a dozen ship types all suited to different playstyles, randomized galaxies so no two playthroughs are ever the same, and a difficulty very much in-tune with the genre it comes from -- it's quite easy to get killed misjudging a situation or taking too big a risk.Travel from encounter to encounter is turn-based (the enemy fleet pursuing you only advances when you choose to warp to the next system), but combat and ship operations are real-time. To avoid being overwhelmed by the concerns of surviving a fight in space, the pause feature (Spacebar) allows you to queue commands to execute when you unpause.It's a fairly small game which won't offer you 8-hour playthroughs or awesome graphics, but what content it does have is well worth the price tag.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												FTL: Faster Than Light is a spectacular game of both luck and strategy that will leave you crying with frustration at times but leave you wanting more. It has a wonderfully basic yet engaging interface and a witty charm that can leave you laughing or fuming at it's antics. The game requires you to make your way across 8 maps, each filled with unknown horrors that can leave you dead in the water. It has a combat system that requires planning, consistent pausing, and the occasional lucky shot. The game itself it often decided on your choice of upgrades, weapons, and wether or not you chose to give fuel to a stranded ship. Each adventure you undertake is very different, and that is one of the key appeals of FTL, its replay value.As an overall FTL is a fabulous game that i would recommend to all.

												I bought FTL on a recommendation from a friend, and never looked back. It brings me back to the good old days of gaming, when gameplay was paramount, and simple graphics were all you ever needed. It is one of my most played games in my list. Needless to say, Ive only ever destroyed the mothership once, but i've got that blood thirst that just keeps coming back. The game is amazingly addictive, and the disasters, well, they just unfold like a snowball screaming down a mountain side hellbent on squashing you. But I say no! I won't go down without a fight, Hell, I just clawed back from only 1 health bar, and another time I killed all those damn intruders with my only guy. I won't let them take me until I do just one more FTL jump... come on ship... just hold together. I hope to ch***t that last power upgrade did the trick, because last time, in that thunderous nebula, I nearly got my hull ripped in half! Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ why did I jump there? Dammit, why didn't I repair at that last station....♥♥♥♥♥♥ no time to whinge... No wait, I think I can do this... I just need to..... Well, you get the idea. This is what makes the game so great! :-)Well, lets just say, you know your hooked when: 1. You buy the FTL soundtrack because you been humming the tunes in your head on the way to work. And at work....2. You lose sleep and have work the next day, but that next FTL jump is soo close you can taste it..3. You backup your FTL profile cause you just can' bear to loose all those sweet upgrades...4. You keep wishing there was another FTL upgrade coming out next year...5. You still play this game well after one year when you bought it. Wow, thats saying something...6. All of the aboveHas anyone unlocked all the ships yet??I give this game:--------------------10/10 for gameplay   (really, alot of detail and though have gone into this game. Good job!)9/10 for replayability (you never get bored at the variety of sticky situations that do occur)9/10 for difficulty       (the randomness makes it tricky)5/10 for graphics       (I can't flaw the 8-bit graphics though)9/10 for music            (amazing soundtrack... reminicent of so many great SCI-FI games... like galaxy map off mass effec)7/10 for sound           (some of the sounds are a little repitious, but it doesnt bother you)10/10 for stability      (never crashed on me. both in windows or linux)10/10 for timewasting    (games can take 15mins upto several hours of risky yet rewarding FTL jumps)

FTL is a spaceship simulation roguelike-like. Its aim is to recreate the atmosphere of running a spaceship exploring the galaxy. 												Described by many as a 'roguelike-like space game', FTL is an entertainingly frustrating roguelike with a seemingly endless desire to target your life-support systems with lasers, ion bombs, bio-organic death lasers and... well, anything and everything they can throw at you. The game's eerie soundtrack and surprisingly immersive 16-bit graphics do an excellent job of drawing you in long enough for you to grow attached to your little crew of pixelated aliens (or humans, if you're boring!) before they get brutally torn apart while assaulting a rebel frigate, or starved of oxygen because you forgot you left the airlock open. This game is certainly worth Steam's asking price, even if the game isn't massively mod-friendly. Still, I managed to add in some beautiful NASA backgrounds and a few amazing content packs, and I have the technological proficiency of a drunken Mantis!

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												As of the time of writing, I've logged 36 hours playing FTL. It still doesn't feel like enough, and it probably never will, thanks to the exceptional variety and replayability of this particular indie gem.FTL is the answer to the fantasies of anyone who experienced Star Trek, Star Wars, Firefly, Babylon 5, Battlestar Galactica, Farscape, Futurama, or any of a million science-fiction programmes, novels and films, and thought 'I wish I could do that'. And it absolutely lives up to its potential. Beginning with a small ship and a handful of crew, the player must navigate a vast network of star systems, overcoming pirates, solar flares, asteroid fields, slave traders, and the constant pursuit of the Rebel fleet. Death stalks your crew at every turn, and your actions can mean the difference between a swift death in the vacuum and living to fight another day.The mechanics are uncomplicated and impressively well-designed. Ship's systems are powered up and down, crewmates man their stations, usually under heavy fire and whilst trying to affect vital repairs, while a fire rages through the ship and enemy boarders swarm the corridors. FTL is a roguelike game, so re-loading a saved game to try again from the same point isn't an option - if you're dead, you're dead, and you've got to start again from the hangar screen.This can be infuriating at first, but the challenge is well worth taking on. Under such trying conditions, reaching a new sector or beating a previous high-score become truly satisfying achievements. Not to mention the fleet of playable ships which can be gradually unlocked, adding some choice to the starting conditions.FTL provides - as the Vulcans say - (almost) infinite diversity in infinite combinations. Each playthrough is different, with a different crew and different choices, and even the most disastrous run can amount to more staisfaction than some games manage on their best day.If that isn't enough, the creators are planning the release of a new DLC - free of charge - some time in early 2014, featuring a new species, new ships, new weapons, and tweaks to gameplay that should streamline and improve the already impressive experience. FTL frequently features in Steam sales, but it's worth every penny of the full price, and I can only reccomend that you buy it and start playing as soon as possible.

												I've only had this game for two weeks and it's slowly becoming one of my favorite PC games yet. This game is very complex, and has so many opportunities, gameplay styles and an optional Advanced Mode, which was added free by the developer(s). I hope to see more DLC for this game; Mind control and hacking were two features that made the game both hard and fun!Update: Review on Hard Mode + Advanced EditionNot too far from Normal Mode, it brings an entirely new tier to the game. If you thought the game was difficult on Easy Mode without Advanced Edition, you will not want to go near Hard + Advanced. When it comes to scrap rewards, every bit of them are important for Hard Mode. Instead of upgrading reactors and subsystems through the ship prompt, I look for quests for free upgrades or find others that will do it for 1/3 of the cost. You can get good weapons by finding them in abandoned beacons, in any sector. There are alternatives to getting items without purchasing them. The difficult part for some players is to maintain fuel surplus whilst hopping to as many beacons as possible before jumping to a new sector. On top of that, you can't do much against a ship with Advanced content and try to fend off without anything. If you have a ship attacking you with mind control, you can then either hack their mind control to disable it OR use mind control on your own mind-controlled player, it will cancel the two, without using a drone part to disable it.If you want to see how to play FTL with less difficulty and increase your skill at the game, go to my YouTube channel @ youtube.com/nadeshikoencrypted, I will be posting a video about a day or two after I post this updated review.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Amazing gameFTL is a indie game developed by Subset Games who were formed by members from 2K. The gameplay is this game's greatest strength. You star off with one ship and move from from node to node as you try to reach the next sector. Each node may contain an event such as enemy encounter, store, side-quest or random event, but you won't know until you get there (unless you have an upgrade). With each playthrough the area and events change in each time, so no playthrough will be the same. There are also plenty of weapons and augmentations you can find in your travels such as burst laser, missiles and bombs, but only a few will be available for each playthrough.  During the your travels you will face various pirate and other foes in ship to ship combat. The combat involves realtime planning as you have to manage your systems effectively in order to win. In reminiscence of 'Star trek', you need to decide which systems to power up (as you have a limited power supply), which areas of the enemy ship to target and how to manage your crew members in order to win battles. How you manage your ship and crew adds to the tension and excitement of combat. You can pause the game at anytime by pressing 'space bar' which allows you to quickly power up differnet systems in your ships and give orders to your crew.  With each ship you defeat you collect scrap (which is the game's primary currency), which you can use to upgrade your ship or save up for buying something at the store.The main reason I keep coming back to this game is because of the ship unlock feature. In order to get more ships to use in subsequent playthroughs you need to meet specific requirements. For different clases (i.e. A,B,C) you need to gain achivements and requirements with a specific ship. For new ships, you need to meet the special requirements such as meeting a certain event during your journey (which can be difficult as not all events appear in each playthrough). To sum this may become tiresome playing the game over and over again just to get the specific events to unlock the ships you want.The story is quite minimal. Basically you have to send a message to the Federation base to warn them of the Rebel attack.The sound in the game are great at setting the mood. Electronic music works great at building excitement during combat, while quite music makes you feel a sence of loneliness in space. The the weapon sounds are decent at when ships fire. There is no voice acting in the game, but to be honest this game doesn't need it.The only downside to the game is that the difficulty may be unforgiving at times. There is a reliance on 'Luck' in order to get the ideal events to get through the sectors and unlocking ships. You also should ideally get high level by the later sectors in order to survive the encounters there. Finally, the end boss is quite unforgiving and I recommend looking at guides to defeat it.This game got me into rogue-like games and I highly recommend it to everyone.

Posted: March 9, 2015
												I have long been into spaceships and have been looking for a game that best simulates being a starship captain. This game certainly delivers. You are given directed control of all of your ship's systems, including weapons, engines, shields, airlocks, life support, etc. It truly feels like a geek fantasy. FTL combines a fun element of mystery and exploration as well as an excuse to take out your frustration on potentially hostile vessels, most of which will kill you. The game features a wide variety of usuable ships, each of which requires different tactics and playstyles, if you succeed in unlocking them. While the alien species in the game are certainly not particularly creative (rock people, slugs, etc), each race has different strengths and weaknesses that you can exploit to get the maximun efficiency out of your crew. For example, I couldn't help but smile when a giant praying mantis named "Smith" joined the ship's company.A word of caution: it is an exceedingly dangerous galaxy. This game is very unforgiving. While you can save your progress, if your crew members die, they are lost forever. If your ship is destroyed, your save is deleted and you will have to start over. So far, my ship has been blown apart, consumed in a solar flare, and at one point my crew asphixiated due to a life support failure. You will have to rely on your skill, good decision making, and a whole lot of luck to beat this game. For instance, when fleeing space pirates, you might warp into another quadrant, only to find your ship being battered by asteroids. Keep in mind that more than half of the time you will lose, even on the easiest settings (if you value your sanity, play on easy), but that is part of the appeal in a universe where almost every other ship is hunting you. It is not about finishing the game as it is about charting the unknown and encountering other races, hopefully those sympathetic to your cause. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who loves space exploration and doesn't mind losing most of their ships to the cold depths of space.

												Faster than Light is a lot of fun and I love playing it.I do have to warn you though, this game requires a few things:- Patience- Calmness- The acceptence of your doom every god damn playthrough you almost defeat the boss/get to sector 8 :(- The acceptance of the fact that this game isn't just skill but also ALOT of luckYes as the last item indicates, LUCK is quite a mayor part of the game, some people may not necessarily agree with meon that matter, but trust me, it is!Ill explain, as you may have seen in other reviews/ the video/ the description or whatever what, the game has many randomized events with standard options like yes/no and hidden options which you can get depending on what your ship has and contains. (For example, there is a race which is very good with technology. There is a randomized where you have to help a space station disable their defence system, normally you can do this with shooting it or leaving them to their faithes. But with that race you can remotely repair it safely)So these random events give rewards n everything. They are very helpful in progressing into the game. Now ill tell you why this is so luck dependant . Now obviously you have the initial chance of these kind of events of happening, not every playthrough you may get that one event that gives you that amazing amount of scrap (ingame currency).Then the most horrible part. Some events actually have a chance to go wrong. (An example of this is an event where you have the option to defend a space station from alien monster spiders. When agreeing you send your crew into the station and thats where the luck strikes. Sometimes you may end up with a very thankful station giving you stuff, and other times your crew members get eaten :))That long explanation about luck is now done :)Anyhow, DO NOT let yourself be scared by that luck stuff,The game is seriously recommendable because of many thingsincluding:- Randomness (not refering to the luck, but the fact that your playthroughs will never be the same :) )- Requires tactical thinking, what do I want to do next/upgrade/  How do I fight this enemy etc.- The urge to finish your playthrough- The many ships/layouts and achievements you can unlock- It keeps track of your score and stats, so you know what was succesful about your best run.- The Feeling of accomplishment when you finally defeat that **** at sector 8 And then the frustration of RNGesus not being with you for quite a few times is just part of this game :)I do have to mention that sometimes this game can be tiring in how unfruitful a run might be.but then again thats just unlucky :)One final notice: Do not buy this game as a game you plan to play for hours and hours after each other, its just not that kind of game. content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
													FTL has amazed me time and again as a game that really pulls you out of the real world. If you need to escape thoughts of day to day monotony and/or if you enjoy strategy games, there is nothing better than a session or two of FTL. You control several small spacefarers in from top down view on a space cruiser as they journey to save their federation, which seems to maintain justice and peace for all beings in the universe. You fly around in different randomly generated sectors, getting into skirmishes or escaping asteriod storms. You can buy new systems for the ship, upgrade and change weapons and drones, recruits aliens and humans to aid your journey, and explore the dozens of other features crafted to make each adventure take a new shape. The gameplay rewards both long term planning and on-the-fly quick thinking, and the world is just engrossing enough to make your actions feel heroic and your losses devastating. The visual aesthetic and stupendous music make you feel like you are flying around in a vast and open space on your own ship, encountering vile foes, fighting epic battles, making genuine allies, and sometimes just floating around staring at the stars.	So if you need a strategy game that doesn't require hundreds of hours to just get rolling, If you like games from small studios that capitalize on several great ideas working together, or if you would like to just leave the world you are living in for a little while to feel the depth of space and the adventure of saving the galaxy, you should probably play FTL

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												FTL: Faster Than Light is a great game. Here's why:Simple but fitting graphicsAWESOME musicGameplay that is easy to learn but hard to masterUnfettered moral choicesIntresting, self-realized storiesTrue, the game is difficult, but keep in mind that this is meant to be a "rogue-like" game. In this genre, death is not failure nessesarily. Death is merely a part of the process of playing. Giving up is failing.I specifically noted the moral choices becuase they were done in such a way as to almost not be moral choices at all. Oftentimes in random encounters, you will be given two or more options on how to approach the situation. These options can seem like definite "good" or "bad" moral choices, but the game does not impose these in gameplay. There is no morality meter, or even any real consequences to your choice beyond the immediate moment. Flavor-text will sometimes paint an action as morally reprehensible, but it rarely shows any of them as morally "correct". This game is full of moral gray areas and places where you must fill in the blanks yourself story-wise. After a few hours of playing I found myself wondering if the group I was supposedly working for were actually the bad guys, and those I was fighting were in the right. At no point did the game overtly prompt me to think like this.In short, this game is worth the money. Buy it.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												This is a fun game, but you have to go into it with the understanding that your skill level will plateau after about 5 - 10 hours, but that does not mean that you will be able to ever win the game except by sheer luck. You can lose from lack of skill, but you cannot win from skill. I have repeatedly lost on the final boss because I never got good weapons all the way through the game. Due to the way the shield system works, it is really helpful to have lasers that fire lots of shots. On one playthrough, I got a bunch of these and just totally dominated everything. On many other playthroughs, I didn't and lost. In general, the weapons are really imbalanced, in large part because all of the missle and bomb weapons require missles, which are in short supply, so you can't use very many missle weapons. This forces you to use laser weapons most of the time. However, once you start using laser weapons, you probably want to jettison missle weapons because laser and missle weapons don't have great synergy (although there are ways to make it work), Most of the weapons are worthless and it's annoying to find stores in the game thathave three terrible weapons for sale. I think I will look for cheats that will give me higher odds of getting useful weapons and completely remove the terrible weapons.In spite of these issues, I think it's a fun game and would recommend trying it out. But wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Like many other reviewers here I got this game on a whim while it was on sale based on the current reviews. Shortly put, this is probably the best thing I have ever gotten for under $2. I would easily pay $10 for this game had I known how good it was.The mechanics are easy to learn and understand, but the game is probably impossible to master given how random it is. The difficulty is up there, but that makes succeeding so rewarding, and it will keep you coming back to try and finish over and over. In a nutshell, the game is like Oregon Trail, but in a spaceship. Your objective is to get the important data you are carrying back to the Federation Fleet, and not turn into space dust along the way.I simply can't recommend this game enough, especially given how cheap it generally is. The only con is the punishing difficulty, but in my opinion it is just punishing enough to feel rewarding.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												One of the best and the most detailed indie games I've ever played. You have to keep in mind tons of aspects just to keep your ship in a working condition and being able to proceed to further stages. Various locations can contain different events: from ships seeking for help and stores to hostile ships and anomalies. This game forces you to make choices all the time and each one affects the gameplay in different ways. Sometimes you get an additional crew member from an abandoned ship, or get trapped after trying to chase the enemy that tried to run away from the battle. All I have to say is that it takes a lot of coordination and strategy and it's one of the most difficult games to beat, at least for me. I've never been a fan of games like this but FTL is something special and it's definitely a breath of fresh in my opinion.This is a really versatile game and you'll love it.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2013
												This game is just as brutal as Don't Starve. But in Don't Starve, you at least have a chance. In this game, it's balls hard, to the point where you'll need leperchaun magic for you to win.Alright, maybe that wasn't as well of a explanation that I thought, but FTL is hard as♥♥♥♥♥♥ You'll be multi tasking and focusing on so many things, it's insane. The game is a pixelated rouge like, being when you die, you die. But not your character, your ship. There's two ways for you to lose in FTL: Your ships hull breaking, causing a massive atomic bomb going inside the ship, being able to compete against the explosion of the Deathstar from A New Hope.Alright, that too seemed exagerrated. The games premise is that your part of the Federation, you just found some secret blue prints on destroying the Rebel Flagship:   the big momma of the Rebel ships. I'll get to that thing later. But, you'll be travelling beacon to beacon, fighting ships, and going through choices. Now, each choice will depend on your ship, your arsenal, and your crews life. There'll be a dice roll going on behind the scenes choosing your every fate. I know I may be rushing through this, I'll probably revise it later, but let me talk about the final boss: The Rebel Flagship.Good God is this thing impossible to kill. It's not only hard to reach the final sector, but you have to fight through a 3 part boss with this thing, while it's trying to reach your central base. The thing is absolutely insane, having such a dense shield, a large amount of crew members, drones, and arsenal.Let me just leave it here, this game has good music, gameplay is satisfying, it's good overall. Just don't get your hopes too high on defeating the final boss.

Fully recommended.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2013
												This game sucked me in extremely fast. I didn't buy it until a friend started playing it, and after watching him, I had to try it myself. The game has a very high replay value, but that might be due to the game's quite short playthrough.To start, the game is brutal and unforgiving. Making mistakes will quickly lead to a game over, and sometimes the RNG plays dirty by giving you time and time again the negative side of every random event. The enemies scale quickly, so you'll need to find a way to keep the pace. The first 10, maybe even 20 times you're going to lose. On easy.However, once you've got an understanding of how the game works, it's not as random and luck based as people make it out to be. Being tactical about your movements and not taking needless risks will take you consistently to the end of the game. Using resource management for your ship can save you tons of cash that you can use to upgrade other things or purchase more weapons at stores. Playing smart will almost always win, except for the very worst generated maps.No matter what type of gamer you are, I highly recommend this game. For $10, it's well worth the money.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I absolutely recommend this game. It's not the open world space game you might hope for (look to upcoming titles like Limit Theory,[ltheory.com] Wayfarer: The Outer Reaches,[brightspritegames.com] No Man's Sky,[www.no-mans-sky.com]Elite: Dangerous,[elite.frontier.co.uk] or Star Citizen[robertsspaceindustries.com] for those). However, despite that, it manages to pull off an incredibly intense space experience within the constraints it puts itself in. You're the director of the crew of a ship trying to get from point A to point B while fleeing a pursuing Rebel fleet that has all but destroyed your Federation, yet you carry vital cargo that may somehow turn the tide. It's never entirely clear what that cargo is, as the story plays pretty fast and loose, as you explore some distant reaches of space, fighting pirates, helping other intelligent species as well as being attacked by them, and coming across some fascinating anomalies as you go from beacon to beacon and sector to sector until you make it to the final, eighth sector. Throughout all this, chances are you will die. A lot. This falls into the roguelike genre that has been popular recently, but with the great difference of being scifi amidst a bunch of more fantasy style games. Albeit, if you'd like more scifi roguelikes you may look into Bionic Dues[arcengames.com] for another recent scifi entry into the genre (unfortunately minus the space, but fortunately with the mechs!).That being said, that factor alone makes it well worth purchasing in my opinion (though preferably from GOG or Humble Store), but even more than that is that with the recent introduction of Advanced Edition content, the game has only gotten even better than before. Toss in mods and the fun stories you'll get from close scrapes with death from various playthroughs, and you have countless hours of fun, many of my own not counted here from playing the DRM-free version more on the side. Ask yourself, do you want to be able to have the virtual experience of suffocating would-be pirates or saboteaurs teleporting aboard your ship? Do you want to be saved by your enemy trying to hack an already destroyed subsystem incidentally shutting the doors to it, restoring oxygen in the rooms and allowing you to do repairs after you fend it off? Then you want FTL. Other space games may let you command fleets, but few let you manage the frantic internal affairs of the crew trying to hold everything together.

Posted: September 26, 2012
												A hectic race through the galaxy to save the Federation from the rebels - or die trying. Likely the latter.A roguelike spaceship simulator with real time (yet pausable) fights - every attempt is bound to be different. And then you unlock different ship layouts to get even more variety.Being random is the name of the game: random encounters in randomly themed and laid out sectors of the galaxy, with random rewards or punishments... Decisions, risk taking and trade offs abound. Yet the overall theme is nicely focused and I dig the space opera setup (even if fridge logic makes you question some stuff).One thing is certain, the odds are against you (at least on normal difficulty - 1st game I felt compelled to play on easy). As the author tips you off, "death is part of the fun - no, really". It's very addicting though, in a gambling sort of way I guess - you swear the next time will go better. And somehow, you do improve overall.This game is incredibly good at what it does!

Posted: November 27, 2016
												If you ever wondered what being the captain of a spaceship in hostile space was like, this is the game for you.  Like "Star Trek", your experienced crew and technological advances will save the day again and again.  Unlike "Star Trek", you have to foot the bill.  Hull repairs cost.  Weapon upgrades cost.  Ship systems cost limited power.  Better trained crew costs.  Fuel costs.  Even the Missiles your ship can fire aren't free.Tough choices abound.  Do I upgrade the weapons or the shields?  Do I purchase that awesome weapon or use several smaller ones?  Do I get involved in the conflicts I come across and try to be a hero or remain content to simply survive?Which crew member do I send to repair the broken Oxygen system and which stays at their post during the heated battle?This game is full of random events in a randomly generated galaxy.  There are countless strategies to employ, new ships to unlock, and suprises along the way.  As many different ways there are to win, there are even more ways to die in the infinite coldness of space.  And believe me, you'll find them, and be even more motivated to start up a new game.  "If only I'd purchased that shield upgrade instead of installing that shiny Mind Control device..."Space is unforgiving, but the Space Bar is your best friend!

												I've only had this game for two weeks and it's slowly becoming one of my favorite PC games yet. This game is very complex, and has so many opportunities, gameplay styles and an optional Advanced Mode, which was added free by the developer(s). I hope to see more DLC for this game; Mind control and hacking were two features that made the game both hard and fun!Update: Review on Hard Mode + Advanced EditionNot too far from Normal Mode, it brings an entirely new tier to the game. If you thought the game was difficult on Easy Mode without Advanced Edition, you will not want to go near Hard + Advanced. When it comes to scrap rewards, every bit of them are important for Hard Mode. Instead of upgrading reactors and subsystems through the ship prompt, I look for quests for free upgrades or find others that will do it for 1/3 of the cost. You can get good weapons by finding them in abandoned beacons, in any sector. There are alternatives to getting items without purchasing them. The difficult part for some players is to maintain fuel surplus whilst hopping to as many beacons as possible before jumping to a new sector. On top of that, you can't do much against a ship with Advanced content and try to fend off without anything. If you have a ship attacking you with mind control, you can then either hack their mind control to disable it OR use mind control on your own mind-controlled player, it will cancel the two, without using a drone part to disable it.If you want to see how to play FTL with less difficulty and increase your skill at the game, go to my YouTube channel @ youtube.com/nadeshikoencrypted, I will be posting a video about a day or two after I post this updated review.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Amazing gameFTL is a indie game developed by Subset Games who were formed by members from 2K. The gameplay is this game's greatest strength. You star off with one ship and move from from node to node as you try to reach the next sector. Each node may contain an event such as enemy encounter, store, side-quest or random event, but you won't know until you get there (unless you have an upgrade). With each playthrough the area and events change in each time, so no playthrough will be the same. There are also plenty of weapons and augmentations you can find in your travels such as burst laser, missiles and bombs, but only a few will be available for each playthrough.  During the your travels you will face various pirate and other foes in ship to ship combat. The combat involves realtime planning as you have to manage your systems effectively in order to win. In reminiscence of 'Star trek', you need to decide which systems to power up (as you have a limited power supply), which areas of the enemy ship to target and how to manage your crew members in order to win battles. How you manage your ship and crew adds to the tension and excitement of combat. You can pause the game at anytime by pressing 'space bar' which allows you to quickly power up differnet systems in your ships and give orders to your crew.  With each ship you defeat you collect scrap (which is the game's primary currency), which you can use to upgrade your ship or save up for buying something at the store.The main reason I keep coming back to this game is because of the ship unlock feature. In order to get more ships to use in subsequent playthroughs you need to meet specific requirements. For different clases (i.e. A,B,C) you need to gain achivements and requirements with a specific ship. For new ships, you need to meet the special requirements such as meeting a certain event during your journey (which can be difficult as not all events appear in each playthrough). To sum this may become tiresome playing the game over and over again just to get the specific events to unlock the ships you want.The story is quite minimal. Basically you have to send a message to the Federation base to warn them of the Rebel attack.The sound in the game are great at setting the mood. Electronic music works great at building excitement during combat, while quite music makes you feel a sence of loneliness in space. The the weapon sounds are decent at when ships fire. There is no voice acting in the game, but to be honest this game doesn't need it.The only downside to the game is that the difficulty may be unforgiving at times. There is a reliance on 'Luck' in order to get the ideal events to get through the sectors and unlocking ships. You also should ideally get high level by the later sectors in order to survive the encounters there. Finally, the end boss is quite unforgiving and I recommend looking at guides to defeat it.This game got me into rogue-like games and I highly recommend it to everyone.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
 FTL is a game that sets the standard for indies Some information you should know: i've played this game for 128 hours, i've unlocked every ship and have done multiple playthroughs with each one, with this out of the way i feel confident that i will create a review that covers the entirety of the game Storyline/Lore FTL is a game that takes place in the distant future, the start of the game tells you two basic things: there are two (known) main factions in this universe, The Rebels and The Federation, both of these factions are at war with the federation on the losing end. You are a member of the federation tasked with bringing critical information to the federation command that will flip the table in their favor, after this the lore is vague and is up to the player to piece it together. Gameplay The games mechanics are simple and easy to understand, your screen is always focused on your ship, from which you can give crew orders, power weapons and other systems. In order to beat the game you have to travel from sector to sector until you reach the final zone, during your travels in sectors you will have encounters that can make or break your run, the game punishes you heavily for not thinking your choices through with loss of crew and hull damage being a few of them. Ship encounters are mostly where the true game is at, the battle mechanics consist of you and your opponents firing projectiles at each others ship until one dies (it's a game over if you lose the battle) in order to avoid death the player must time their shots and manage shields, later on you will have access to powerful equipments such as drone bays, mind control and system hacking all of which can turn the tide of a battle, easily making the battle sysem the most challenging and enjoyable part of the game. Soundtrack  The soundtrack of the game is amazing, there is no way to put it, the tracks drive the emotionand feeling of the game no matter how far you got or where you are. I highly recommend the soundtrack to anyone who likes powerful and ambient music. Conclusion I highly recommend this game, it is very obvious that alot of love and care went into refining the core mechanics to make it a very enjoyable experience and one that truly sets the standard for indie games.
