												Like many other reviewers here I got this game on a whim while it was on sale based on the current reviews. Shortly put, this is probably the best thing I have ever gotten for under $2. I would easily pay $10 for this game had I known how good it was.The mechanics are easy to learn and understand, but the game is probably impossible to master given how random it is. The difficulty is up there, but that makes succeeding so rewarding, and it will keep you coming back to try and finish over and over. In a nutshell, the game is like Oregon Trail, but in a spaceship. Your objective is to get the important data you are carrying back to the Federation Fleet, and not turn into space dust along the way.I simply can't recommend this game enough, especially given how cheap it generally is. The only con is the punishing difficulty, but in my opinion it is just punishing enough to feel rewarding.

												This game is extremely fun and challenging.  Its a great game for 10 bucks and when it goes on sale it is an absolute steal.  Basically this game is Star Trek hardcore version.  Negotiating is not always an option and it can be difficult to know when to run and when to fight.  Its a rogue like exploration game with a great combat element to it.  You manage and upgrade your ship while trying to stay ahead of those dang rebels.  Its a game that is easy to learn the basics of, but very difficult to master.  I have beat it many times now, but it took me a very long time to understand how best to manage my resources and required a lot of fun experimenting in order to win (it also took many many hours to finally beat the game the first time).  I'm am still finding new ways to play this game and loving every minute of it.  I can't recommend this game enough.  And if anyone wants a funny and entertaining review of this game look  up pyrion flax FTL, and watch his guide to the game.  Yes this game is difficult and sometimes unforgiving, but it is so much fun to play.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2013
												Love this game.Its a sci-fi rogue type game. You get a ship and some crew and a mission.Your being chased by a large group that want to kil you.You have to move from spade node to space node til you reach the node that has the FTL gate that will allow you to warp to the next sector. As you go through the sectors you get all sorts of things that can happen,You can run into slavers and decide to attack them or let them be,find distress calls for help which could be traps.There are a few space enviornment effects that throw you for a loop solar flares from a star, or loss of some key systems via a nebula. Enemy ships you might run into with chances to either attack them,avoid them,attack them then show mercy, or take them down,etc.You can upgrade your ship. Weapons,shields,doors,oxygen,repair drones,defense,drones,offenive drones,teleport station,etc.On top of just running into the enemy you have to worry about what happens on your ship itself (which you can cause to happen to your enemies as well). Fires,hull breaches,boarding parties,systems disruption,etc. Just think Star Trek ,how they had all kinds of crap happen on the ship. Nver seen that? Then think about Battlestar Galactica, a Naval ship in  war movie,etc. Lots of things that can happn aboard your ship.Game is short in terms of length of gameplay time it might take for you to go from sector to sector (I average 30-45min per sector) 8sectors in total. I advise you play on Normal (games version of hard) if you do not want a easy time of it. There are a various number of ships you unlock via different achievements completed. Had to write all of this so you could get a good understanding of how fun yet complex the game is. Still not convinced if its for you? Then watch a Lets play series on youtube. This game is a you love it or hate it type so not for everyone.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2013
												I was honestly not expecting to like this game as much as I did.  Upgrade your ship, explore the galaxy, improve your crew's skills, and do it all with the knowledge that you are probably gonna die soon.My worst death was when I was in one of my best games.  After a major ship battle, I was unable to repair my oxygen supply in time.  So everyone on my ship died nearly simultaneously.  Bummer.If you're ok with hard games, I'd recommend this.  There are some decent mods available as well, including a few which make the game easier.  You could say that it's cheating, but I actually had a lot of fun being a little more powerful.  It's almost like the game is balanced really far against you, and the mods make it barely in your favor (in line with most games, I think).Update:  After playing through this game many more times over a few years, I've become extremely impressed with it.  There is no game that gets across this feeling of exploring the universe.  Obviously, it lacks a lot of features that other space games have, such as landing on planets, building a trading empire, or dogfighting... but there is absolutely no other game that I can find that does what this game does.  It feels a lot like Star Trek: Voyager... traveling a long distance, with episodes for each jump, and seasons for each sector.  I wish I could find something else that scratched this particular itch as well as FTL.  But FTL is one of a kind.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												This game is so exciting and no doubt one of the most difficult simulation game I ever played. I haven't managed to finish the Normal difficulty though (maybe it's just me), and there so much surprise on your adventure to the final sector (from vanishing of the crew due to huge monolith to the crew zombified and turn against you—and you have to kill him with your own crew).The permadeath feature is essential to the constant tension and managing your encounters with different ships and dangers, to the final sector which you have to fight the Rebel mothership which evolves after you beat it in the first place—and not to mention the huge amount of replayability due to diverse randomly generated worlds and scenarios (and the recent updates add tons of additional content, from ship, story, to alien race).However, as good as a game might be, there's always a room for improvement. Though this game features Cloud Sync, the game save file is NOT compatible cross-OSes (I played on Mac and Windows) which is quite a drawback for people who constantly use different OS on everyday basis. The achievement is saved in your save file too, which means it's not saved on Steam and again—it's not compatible with cross-OS save files. I really, really hope the dev will address this issue pretty soon.However, those issues is quite minor compared to the fun you gonna have from this game. Sim-fans and Sci-Fi-fans who want a taste of their intergalactic adventure from the comfort of your home (with retro graphics), this game is a must buy.9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 9, 2013
												Love this game.Its a sci-fi rogue type game. You get a ship and some crew and a mission.Your being chased by a large group that want to kil you.You have to move from spade node to space node til you reach the node that has the FTL gate that will allow you to warp to the next sector. As you go through the sectors you get all sorts of things that can happen,You can run into slavers and decide to attack them or let them be,find distress calls for help which could be traps.There are a few space enviornment effects that throw you for a loop solar flares from a star, or loss of some key systems via a nebula. Enemy ships you might run into with chances to either attack them,avoid them,attack them then show mercy, or take them down,etc.You can upgrade your ship. Weapons,shields,doors,oxygen,repair drones,defense,drones,offenive drones,teleport station,etc.On top of just running into the enemy you have to worry about what happens on your ship itself (which you can cause to happen to your enemies as well). Fires,hull breaches,boarding parties,systems disruption,etc. Just think Star Trek ,how they had all kinds of crap happen on the ship. Nver seen that? Then think about Battlestar Galactica, a Naval ship in  war movie,etc. Lots of things that can happn aboard your ship.Game is short in terms of length of gameplay time it might take for you to go from sector to sector (I average 30-45min per sector) 8sectors in total. I advise you play on Normal (games version of hard) if you do not want a easy time of it. There are a various number of ships you unlock via different achievements completed. Had to write all of this so you could get a good understanding of how fun yet complex the game is. Still not convinced if its for you? Then watch a Lets play series on youtube. This game is a you love it or hate it type so not for everyone.

												When I play this game, I feel like I want to punch myself in the face multiple times. "♥♥♥♥♥♥ dude, come on, focus on the crew!" "IDIOT! I'm an idiot! I should have redeployed my drones!" "GODS DAMN IT! If I got my Engi(neer) into the damn cockpit, I would have dodged those rockets!" Nonetheless, this game is great. You'd like it a lot if you enjoy watching crew members die in fires, rooms with no air, rooms targeted by rocket launchers, rooms targeted by lasers, rooms targeted by teleporting bombs, rooms that have been hacked, rooms attacked by drones, rooms where enemies have teleported onto your ship, on board enemy ships because you forgot to teleport them back, and in events the game developers crafted to pull at your hearstrings when your favorite crew member is pulled out an airlock or continually gets younger to the point where they no longer exist. The combat is awesome, different ways to fight back the pirates, rebels, slave traders and drone ships you encounter. The events make you decide for the best of the crew and your ship, choose wrong or get unlucky and you might be down a crew member or a few hull points. RNG is a big factor in this game, as with all roguelikes, but here, it's easy to be SOL. Need repairs after a fierce fight? Sorry! No shops anywhere near you. Want a specific race to join your ship? Nope! Get ALL HUMANS! Aye, want the biggest guns of them all? NET! Get Burst Laser I's all day long! Only get this game if you're not afraid to lose a lot and rage to the point of insanity, because you WILL die, and you WILL rage. There are, however, comedic events at times, which would help with relaxing after you, say, miraculously survived on 1 hull point. I'd give this game a 8/10. To those who buy this game, good luck. Live short and die well! o7

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This recommendation has been a long time coming, I think. One of my favorites of the past few years, honestly. Hugely addicting, but not in the lame "second job" kind of way. You want to keep playing it, because you're sure that next time, you'll be able to do better, and you want to prove it to yourself. Especially since it's often so painfully easy to see where you went wrong in hindsight... "ARGH! I should have spent that scrap on improving the blast doors!" or "Why didn't I save scrap on upgrading weapons power when I upgraded the reactor!" You'll have those issues a lot too, because as expensive as things are (especially in stores) you'll always be struggling for how you should ration your scrap. But instead of making it feel like the game is dangling a carrot in front of you, it just adds to the tenseness of play. Which is wild given the game's smooth and somewhat slow pace. Since, sure, you could hang around and try and build up the scrap to get that shiny new transporter... but the Rebel fleet in already on its way. So, you better jump. Now. JUMP! Really just an excellently done game, and incredible how all the different parts come together. There's nothing else quite like it.

												This game goes down as one of my favorite games of all time. It really does give the feeling of being a spaceship captain in the depths of space. There are a thousand options to make during your journey, and it makes every playthrough different and unique. You can also customize your ship to fit your playstyle. Like unleashing barrages of laser and missile fire? Enjoy shutting down their engines and letting your boarding crews clean up the enemy crew? Feel like commanding drones to cripple their ship and block missile fire for you? All three are viable options for you to focus on. I admit that at this point, the dialogue options and random events do feel a bit scripted, but I've put in A LOT of time into this game to get to this point. It does add to the adventure and intensity though. Do you risk your own crew members to gain more crew? Do you risk hull damage to gain more scrap or a weapon? No matter how much you've played, the game will still feel fresh and new every playthrough.Also, be sure to name your crew after friends and family members. It heightens the drama.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2012
												FTL is what I'd describe as a spaceship micromanagement roguelike with its randomly generated sectors (floors), beacons (rooms), and rewards in each beacon. There are plenty of different ships, weapons, crew species, drones, and augmentations that completely change how you need to play. You use scrap gotten throughout the game as currency in stores or to power up your ship. You learn more as you play and experiment (like how upgrading engines and doors is important!). FTL isn't very fast-paced, with a bunch of pausing and a recharge-based attacking system. It also doesn't require a good computer to play (it may still lag, but FTL plays in a way where that doesn't get in the way too much). You're often given choices as you jump into beacons, so your judgement is put to the test (along with 'How do I spend this scrap?). I give this game a hearty recommendation if you're even remotely interested in an action/strategy game like this one!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2012
												FTL is probably going to go down as my favorite indie game of 2012. Almost a perfect combination of Master of Orion, Star Control, and the essence of Star Trek, FTL is a DOS-style space "exploration" game where you control one ship and its crew, as you try to outrun the persuing enemy force on your way to your home system to deliver vital info (which triggers the final series of boss battles). Along the way there are many different random encounters, most being some kind of ship-to-ship combat. You find new equipment and crew members to outfit your ship, and eventually you unlock new ships and outfits for ships as you play through the game. A few words of warning however: FTL is crazy-addictive, you'll find yourself playing until sunrise if not careful; also FTL does not have a save/load feature that allows you to turn back time - your decisions matter and a few bad choices will quickly spiral into your ship, crew, and the entire mission being lost. Overall 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to know the feeling of commanding your own starship? Boldly going where no man has gone before?FTL: Faster Than Light is an excellent way to do just that. You are the captain of a starship and crew, exploring space while fleeing the ever pursuant rebel fleet. The challenges you face include combat with enemy ships, randomly generated quests, and a variety of scenarios where you must make a choice based on your current situation rather than the obvious "good" or "bad" choice.EXAMPLE: You're almost out of fuel as you make the jump to the next beacon on your map toward the exit. You encounter a pirate fighter ship attacking an already damaged ship. The ship is of the same race as two of your loyal crew members and clearly needs help or else will be destroyed. The pirate ship offers you a portion of the fuel stores they'll get from the helpless ship as compensation for standing back. Do you take the fuel bribe, needing it desperately to get to the exit beacon? Or do you intervene and fight the pirates, risking your own ship and precious resources with no assurance of a reward for winning the fight?I know, I feel it too.This game has had me shouting commands like "All power to weapons, I need halberds online now!" and "Ok, you get shields back up, and you put out that fire in med bay. Open the airlocks in engineering, suffocate that boarding party!" at my screen as I explored the universe and destroyed other ships for loot.I can't wait to sink my teeth into the future of FTL: Faster Than Light.Buy it now. Buy it so much. You'll get hours upon hours of fun and then some!

												Very fun, but very hard.The way the levels are generated results in some challenging playthroughs. Sometimes you will lose crew members and take heavy damamge in the first few minutes of a new game (in which case it's best to restart). content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												I'll say it, I love games that involve anything with space, and this game has plenty of it. I won't bore you with that so I'll just get on with the review. Graphics- 8.5/10I love the cartoon-like style of the game as well as they way the game looks as a whole. Some things like the background for the nebulas look a bit off, but it's still lovely to the eyes. The character sprites are small and not really all that detailed, but with the variety of them it still somewhat makes up for it.Control- 9.5/10I don't have much to say on the control, it's very simple and easy to work with and there's really no problems with it. The reason I have it as 9.5 is due to the fact that there isn't a lot towards controls other than using the mouse unless you use hotkeys.Story- 9/10The story as short as it is is pretty enjoyable. With this kind of game I think of how you play the game is how the story is written for your experience in the game. It's choice-based and with eachchoice gives a different outsome to how you and your crew and your ship are affected. It's all very fun and exciting to have control of how the game's story will progress.Gameplay- 9/10The gameplay is again, quite simple. Attacking an enemy ship with your various weapons and equipment is very nice to the eyes and fun to do for it's simplicity and the idea of having limited scrap and supplies makes quite a challenge at times if you wind up in a tight situation. Though the gameplay is only this good if you know what you're doing, and if you don't then I guarantee you will die a lot. Managing everything can become a hassle at time, as I said you have limited scrap and supplies so you need to use them sparringly and prcisely on what you feel is best and when is best. This game isn't one you can really ♥♥♥♥ around in unless you're doing really well and can afford to. Other than that it's a very fun and challenging game and I feel that it's one that deserves a sequel if one hasn't been made yet.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2013
												I was honestly not expecting to like this game as much as I did.  Upgrade your ship, explore the galaxy, improve your crew's skills, and do it all with the knowledge that you are probably gonna die soon.My worst death was when I was in one of my best games.  After a major ship battle, I was unable to repair my oxygen supply in time.  So everyone on my ship died nearly simultaneously.  Bummer.If you're ok with hard games, I'd recommend this.  There are some decent mods available as well, including a few which make the game easier.  You could say that it's cheating, but I actually had a lot of fun being a little more powerful.  It's almost like the game is balanced really far against you, and the mods make it barely in your favor (in line with most games, I think).Update:  After playing through this game many more times over a few years, I've become extremely impressed with it.  There is no game that gets across this feeling of exploring the universe.  Obviously, it lacks a lot of features that other space games have, such as landing on planets, building a trading empire, or dogfighting... but there is absolutely no other game that I can find that does what this game does.  It feels a lot like Star Trek: Voyager... traveling a long distance, with episodes for each jump, and seasons for each sector.  I wish I could find something else that scratched this particular itch as well as FTL.  But FTL is one of a kind.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
 FTL is a game that sets the standard for indies Some information you should know: i've played this game for 128 hours, i've unlocked every ship and have done multiple playthroughs with each one, with this out of the way i feel confident that i will create a review that covers the entirety of the game Storyline/Lore FTL is a game that takes place in the distant future, the start of the game tells you two basic things: there are two (known) main factions in this universe, The Rebels and The Federation, both of these factions are at war with the federation on the losing end. You are a member of the federation tasked with bringing critical information to the federation command that will flip the table in their favor, after this the lore is vague and is up to the player to piece it together. Gameplay The games mechanics are simple and easy to understand, your screen is always focused on your ship, from which you can give crew orders, power weapons and other systems. In order to beat the game you have to travel from sector to sector until you reach the final zone, during your travels in sectors you will have encounters that can make or break your run, the game punishes you heavily for not thinking your choices through with loss of crew and hull damage being a few of them. Ship encounters are mostly where the true game is at, the battle mechanics consist of you and your opponents firing projectiles at each others ship until one dies (it's a game over if you lose the battle) in order to avoid death the player must time their shots and manage shields, later on you will have access to powerful equipments such as drone bays, mind control and system hacking all of which can turn the tide of a battle, easily making the battle sysem the most challenging and enjoyable part of the game. Soundtrack  The soundtrack of the game is amazing, there is no way to put it, the tracks drive the emotionand feeling of the game no matter how far you got or where you are. I highly recommend the soundtrack to anyone who likes powerful and ambient music. Conclusion I highly recommend this game, it is very obvious that alot of love and care went into refining the core mechanics to make it a very enjoyable experience and one that truly sets the standard for indie games.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												In FTL: Faster Than Light, the player navigates a spaceship through a randomly generated galaxy with the goal of aiding the Galactic Federation against the Rebellion forces that have overwhelmed them. The game is divided into 8 "sectors;" the first sector is by default a neutral zone, and the 8th is hostile, consisting of the final boss. All sectors in between have a randomly generated tree, allowing the player to decide between navigating varying levels of friendly, neutral, and hostile zones. Each sector starts the player on the left side of the screen, with the goal to advance to the next sector towards the right side, and a random number of beacons in between, spread throughout the screen. The player clicks on these beacons to travel through the sector, with each beacon containing a random event. The player gets to decide which order to visit beacons, but Rebellion forces push from left to right, and if they reach the player, reaching the goal becomes much more difficult, with all events on beacons changed to a battle with Rebellion forces. Battles can be taken at the player's own pace, as they can be paused at any moment for the player to make changes to his or her strategy. It's up to the player to decide the best way to upgrade and equip their ship, but the randomness of the game encourages the player to be versatile and adapt to whatever he or she is offered between various stores, salvages, and decisions. Overall, FTL: Faster Than Light has been a pretty solid experience. Each full playthrough takes about 1-3 hours, but no two playthroughs are identical. There are also many of ships with different layouts, starting weapons, and crew members to choose from, each having their own optimal startegies, further increasing replayability. Subset Games also recently released additional features for free, adding more variety to the game. This game will be a struggle, so don't expect any casual playthroughs, but if you're looking to kill a couple hours with a challenge without any commitment beyond that, FTL is a great way to spend that time.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Let me tell you my story.I used to play a pirated version of the game. I admit it, I didn't help the developers. I wanted do, but as a teen, my parents aren't fond of me spending money on games (they'd rather have me spending a **** ton of money on clothes, being social, whatever..). I took to reddit, and met some really nice people. A guy wanted to trade his extra copy of FTL for a game, but he didnt like my offers, and i respected his refusal like everyone should. Somehow, he saw through our 2 sentence exchange, and realized that I really wanted the legitimate version of the game. Three days after we talked, I booted up steam, and on the top right, i saw the green inbox notification. I opened it, and saw it. The guy from reddit had gifted me the game, even though i didn't give him anything.  He said " If you really like the game that much, here you go. Enjoy".  I don't think i've ever been this grateful to be part of the video game community.This isn't a review for the game. I am reviewing its wonderful community.A roguelike strategy game that involves spaceships doesn't necessarily need a lenghty review. The game is simply 20/10
